captions.text:
There’s no way a fidgety and skeptical news
anchor would ever have started meditating

were it not for the science. The science is
really compelling. It shows that meditation

can boost your immune system, lower your blood
pressure, help you deal with problems ranging

from irritable bowel syndrome to psoriasis.
And the neuroscience is where it really gets

sci-fi. There was a study out of Harvard that
shows that short daily doses of meditation

can literally grow the gray matter in key
areas of your brain having to do with self-awareness

and compassion and shrink the gray matter
in the area associated with stress.

There was also a study out of Yale that looked
at what’s called the default mode network

of the brain. It’s a connected series of
brain regions that are active during most

of our waking hours when we’re doing that
thing that human beings do all the time which

is obsessing about ourselves, thinking about
the past, thinking about the future, doing

anything but being focused on what’s happening
right now. Meditators not only turn off the

default mode network of their brain while
they’re meditating but even when they’re

not meditating. In other words, meditators
are setting a new default mode. And what’s

that default mode? They’re focused on what’s
happening right now.

In sports this is called being in the zone.
It’s nothing mystical. It’s not magical.

You’re not floating off into cosmic ooze.
You are just being where you are – big cliché

in self-help circles is being in the now.
You can use that term if you want but because

it’s accurate. It’s slightly annoying
but it’s accurate. It’s more just being

focused on what you’re doing. And the benefits
of that are enormous. And this is why you’re

seeing these unlikely meditators now, why
you’re seeing the U.S. Marines adopting

it, the U.S. Army, corporate executives from
the head of Ford to the founders of Twitter.

Athletes from Phil Jackson to many, many Olympians.
Scientists, doctors, lawyers, school children.

There’s this sort of elite subculture of
high achievers who are adopting this because

they know it can help you be more focused
on what you’re doing and it can stop you

from being yanked around by the voice in your
head.

My powers of prognostication are not great.
I bought a lot of stock in a company that

made Palm Pilot back in 2000 and that didn’t
go so well for me. But having said that I’m

going to make a prediction. I think we’re
looking at meditation as the next big public

health revolution. In the 1940s if you told
people that you went running they would say,

who’s chasing you. Right now if you tell
people you meditate – and I have a lot of

experience with telling people this, they’re
going to look at you like you’re a little

weird most of the time. That’s going to
change. Meditation is going to join the pantheon

of no brainers like exercise, brushing your
teeth and taking the meds that your doctor

prescribes to you. These are all things that
if you don’t do you feel guilty about. And

that is where I think we’re heading with
meditation because the science is so strongly

suggestive that meditation can do really,
really great things for your brain and for
your body.

The common assumption that we have, and it
may be subconscious, is that our happiness

really depends on external factors – how
was our childhood, have we won the lottery

recently, did we marry well, did we marry
at all. But, in fact, meditation suggests

that happiness is actually a skill, something
you can train just the way you can train your

body in the gym. It’s a self-generated thing.
And that’s a really radical notion. It doesn’t

mean that external circumstances aren’t
going to impact your happiness. It doesn’t

mean you’re not going to be subject to the
vagaries of an impermanent, entropic universe.

It just means you are going to be able to
navigate this with a little bit more ease.

title: Dan Harris: Hack Your Brain's Default Mode with Meditation

comments.text: I read his book 10% Happier. It made me 10% happier while reading it.
comments.author: anH nguyeN

comments.text:
More and more people are doing it and realizing the benefits, specially a 
vast number of athletes and people with stressful jobs (who doesn't have a 
stressful job these days??). Meditation has been proven to bring several 
benefits and it doesn't need to involve any mysticism. A few decades ago, 
if someone saw you running they'd ask you "who are you running from??". Try 
it a few minutes once or twice a day and you will notice the difference in 
a few weeks. 
#UtopiA  ﻿

comments.author: 4everoptimist T

comments.text:
Lol, that's great science has finally "figured out" meditation and the 
areas of the brain that are affected... now they can sit around discussing 
the theory and technical concepts instead of understanding it. We can only 
hope scientists will meditate, if nothing else than to re-humanize the 
severely dehumanized. [See the cat's cradle... see?]
Dollars to donuts, what will end up happening is that they will create and 
contrive highly technical and intricate concepts that will stand in the way 
of any kind of real understanding. That's doing nothing, but creating 
further games. So the next generation will gain only a pedantic knowledge 
of meditation--then students will "study" meditation instead of 
understanding or practicing it--just like every other subject in academia. 
Academia "studies" so much, yet understands so little. Then years down the 
road, this will become a religion and after many decades or centuries this 
knowledge will become so obscured by theory and corrupted with concepts 
that it will be forgotten and replaced will dogmatic beliefs--since no one 
will have any real understanding of it. Hasn't this same pattern happened 
several times throughout history already? The question is can man end this 
pattern? Can man stop creating disorder in the world?
Here we are 2,500 years later and we are just 'relearning' these 
things--the ancient Greeks meditated sitting up with their hand underneath 
their chin.  What are you waiting for?  By all means do it, if it's so 
easy!  Go off and sit in a lotus position with your eyes closed, chant some 
bizarre words, and sit there not thinking--then see how long it will take 
you to understand what it is you're supposed to be doing. My guess is 10 
years.﻿

comments.text:
Yea being in the "now" is good for soldiers and athletes. Plus we're 
already wired to not handle decisions that affect us long term. I think 
these days its a GOOD thing to be stressing about the long term. Living in 
the "now" sounds great and all but its not practical and sounds like a bad 
thing for the average person.
Examples where living in the "now" is bad:

Investing in 401k or buying a new car.
Eating that delicious doughnut or eating a healthy breakfast.
Joining a bowling league or taking a few night time classes to further your 
career.
Watching some youtube videos or helping your kids with their homework.
Gambling with extra money or investing in your home.
Putting 3% down when you buy a home or waiting till you have 20%

On and on and on and on. I could do this all day. In todays modern 
civilization not living in the "now" is key to survival.﻿

comments.author: MinhPhước DevaPunya

comments.text:
I don't know if you've started yet. But the approach is just to calm down 
yourself first. Be comfortable where you are, with limited distraction if 
any (I like to use guided meditations but you can also do it without music 
or guidance).

The basics are really this.
1. Place your focus on a certain aspect that is always there. For instance 
your breath. It can also be the sensation of just being there. Feel how you 
are sitting in the chair. Feel how your body has weight. Just the sense 
that you are there, what is also called the persistent feeling of "I am".

2. When focusing on that aspect you WILL be interrupted by thoughts. This 
is not bad at all, and a big misconception is that you're not allowed to 
think at all. 
You most definitely are, but you should try to keep your focus on that 
single aspect. So when you are drifting away in thought, gently nudge your 
focus back to that aspect.
So the goal is really to detect when you are drifting away in thought and 
notice it as soon as possible, and refocus on that aspect.

3. Repeat until you're done. (I would advice not to use a timer unless you 
want to set a specific time each day, mainly because it will jolt you into 
a scare reaction, which is the opposite of what you are trying to achieve. 
But will be a really really small one compared to when you're not in the 
moment.)

Self-hypnosis is the same thing, it is also meditation but you're imagining 
things at the same time and shifting your focus instead of keeping it at 
one point. It's a powerful tool for reaching inner feelings.
comments.author: RopeNL

comments.text: Meditation is great stuff, I also suggest leaches for erectile dysfunction.﻿
comments.author: Frank Horrigan

comments.text:
Meditation - en kommande hälsorevolution? Ja, jag tror faktiskt det. 
Vetenskapen har nu gjort sitt med att visa dess mätbara fördelar och det 
återstår fortfarande enorma fördelar som (ännu) inte är mätbara. ﻿
comments.author: Magnus Fernström

comments.text:
i want to use the time i am driving around and walking around the 
neighborhood to think of ideas for my book, but i also want to be in the 
now during. can i do both?﻿
comments.author: StudioEthan

comments.text:
+Living Simply thank you, and don't forget taking a shower is also a good 
place to think
comments.author: StudioEthan

comments.text:
Hi Ethan. Yes, it is possible. You might recall that many famous scientific 
problems have been solved when the scientist goes for a walk, or after 
they've had a good nap, and they all of a sudden have a "eureka" moment.
That's because the mind is less distracted during those times, and so our 
subconscious is able to work on the problem with higher degrees of it's 
full capacity. Meditation is something like taking that effect, and 
maximising it to it's highest potential. IIRC Thich Nhat Hanh from Buddhism 
said once that one way they consider the mind, is that it's somewhat like 
an iceberg: the conscious part of the mind is like the part above the 
water, relatively small and powerless, while the store consciousness (or 
subconscious) is more like the part of the iceberg submerged below the 
water - even though we cannot see it, it is far, far more effective and 
powerful. If you leave a problem for it to solve, it will probably come to 
you, and in a far more effective way than simply sitting and beating 
answers out of yourself.
But of course, find what works for you and your book. Give it a try and see 
how you go. :)
comments.author: Living Simply

comments.text: Fantastic. Thank you!﻿
comments.author: Everything Changes
